evidence.text: PRAYER FOR RELIEF  1. To certify the class as defined above at ¶ 52; 2. To declare Grants Pass' campaign to drive homeless people out of the City unconstitutional and enjoin such practices, policies and customs; 3. To issue a declaration that, as applied to plaintiffs, enforcement of GPMC 5.61.020 (the anti-sleeping ordinance), GPMC 5.61.030 (the anti-camping ordinance), GPMC 6.46.090 (the parks anti-camping ordinance), GPMC 6.46.350 (park exclusion ordinance) and criminal trespass laws is an unconstitutional infringement on plaintiffs' Eighth and Fourteenth Amendment rights.
evidence.source_document: Third Amended Class Action Complaint for Injunctive and Declaratory Relief

evidence.text: 4. To issue an injunction prohibiting Grants Pass from enforcement of GPMC 5.61.020 (the anti-sleeping ordinance), GPMC 5.61.030 (the anti-camping ordinance), GPMC 6.46.090 (the parks anti-camping ordinance), GPMC 6.46.350 (park exclusion ordinance) and criminal trespass laws against homeless individuals in Grants Pass who are engaged in the life sustaining activities of resting, sleeping or seeking shelter from the elements, unless and until Grants Pass provides a place where plaintiffs can lawfully engage in necessary life-sustaining activities.
evidence.source_document: Third Amended Class Action Complaint for Injunctive and Declaratory Relief

add_extracted.value: Plaintiff: Injunction prohibiting enforcement of ordinances

evidence.text: Defendant is enjoined from enforcing GPMC 5.61.030 and GPMC 6.46.090 (the camping ordinances) without first giving a person a warning of at least 24 hours before enforcement;

add_extracted.value: Enjoining enforcement of GPMC 5.61.030 and 6.46.090 (camping ordinances) without 24-hour warning

evidence.text: Defendant is enjoined from enforcing GPMC 5.61.030, GPMC 6.46.090 (the camping ordinances) and GPMC 5.57.020(A) (criminal trespassing on city property related to parks) from 9:00 p.m. to 7:30 a.m. during the months of April through September and from 7:00 p.m. to 7:30 a.m. during the months of October to March, in all City parks with the exception of Reinhart Volunteer Park

add_extracted.value: Enjoining enforcement of camping ordinances and criminal trespassing from specific hours during certain months (except Reinhart Volunteer Park)

evidence.text: IT IS SO ORDERED and DATED this 26th day of August, 2020.
DEBRA BLAKE, GLORIA JOHNSON, JOHN LOGAN, individuals, on behalf of themselves and all others similarly situated, Plaintiffs

add_extracted.value: Plaintiff: Debra Blake, Gloria Johnson, John Logan, and all other involuntarily homeless individuals in Grants Pass, Oregon

evidence.text: CITY OF GRANTS PASS, Defendant
Third Amended Class Action Complaint for Injunctive and Declaratory Relief

add_extracted.value: Plaintiffs filed a Third Amended Class Action Complaint for Injunctive and Declaratory Relief on 08/28/2018, seeking to enjoin enforcement of the City's ordinances against homeless individuals.

evidence.text: IT IS SO ORDERED and DATED this 26th day of August, 2020.

add_extracted.value: Court entered Judgment on 08/26/2020, granting partial summary judgment and enjoining enforcement of the camping ordinances without 24-hour warning and during specific hours.

evidence.text: The City had 'zero emergency shelter beds,' and even counting the beds at the Gospel Rescue Mission (GRM), 'which is the only entity in Grants Pass that offers any sort of temporary program for some class members,' 'GRM’s 138 beds would not be nearly enough to accommodate the at least 602 homeless individuals in Grants Pass.'

add_extracted.value: Grants Pass has zero emergency shelter beds, and the Gospel Rescue Mission's 138 beds are insufficient for the 602 homeless individuals in the city.

evidence.text: For respondents, the Ordinances as applied do not criminalize any behavior or conduct related to encampments (such as fires or tents). Instead, the Ordinances target respondents’ status as people without any other form of shelter.

add_extracted.value: Homeless individuals sleep in their cars or on sidewalks because there is no available shelter, and the City's ordinances criminalize sleeping outside with as little as a blanket.

evidence.text: Defendant is enjoined from enforcing GPMC 5.61.030 and GPMC 6.46.090 (the camping ordinances) without first giving a person a warning of at least 24 hours before enforcement;

add_extracted.value: Permanent: Enjoining enforcement of GPMC 5.61.030 and 6.46.090 without 24-hour warning and during specific hours (as per Judgment)

evidence.text: the Court grants plaintiffs’ motion for summary judgment in part and denies it in part

add_extracted.value: Court granted Plaintiffs' Motion for Summary Judgment on the Eighth Amendment claims on August 26, 2020, finding that the City's ordinances violate the Eighth Amendment by criminalizing homelessness.
